author: Freestyle7674754398
body:
Come to the conclusion that the only way to play options is to literally just play the most liquid / biggest names. 

Solely trading SPY / QQQ / AAPL / NVDA / SHOP / AMZN / IWM has worked out so much better for me than playing anything else. You're able to be so much more consistent. 

Also as someone with less than 25k in an account, I've started only ever buying plays that I think are high risk at the end of the day. That way it takes emotion out of it with regards to day trades. 

thanks for reading my blog.

author: CamSlam2902
body: No the growth stocks in this market are based revenue projections and what their potential to grow into is. This constant complaining about the market is just draining. In the last round of earnings it’s been shown for the growth stocks that if there’s a miss on revenue or concerns about meeting growth in revenue there is sharp drops in stock price to reflect. Nvda and amd are no different to this a miss in revenue would tank the stock. If you want to value invest and your valuation tells you that intel is under priced you go for it. But intel isn’t for me could even hit targets last earnings while demand for semiconductors is high while just about every other companies makes fat bags. Any how su bae guiding us what’s the worst that can happen will have bigger problems if the market collapses.

author: Desmater
body:
Energy
Companies not investing into capex but lowering debt, buybacks and dividends. Current prices of $70-85 let's then throw off FCF to buy 10-20% of the float.

Banks and insurance
Higher rates and overall good economy. They have ton of FCF for buybacks and dividend increases. Plus cash to start lending and other investments.

Steel
Steel prices have never been better. EVs, infrastructure and Airplanes need steel. More and more of the world is flying now and growing still. Car makers should start getting chips to restart production. Infrastructure bill in US. EV charging stations will need it. Telecoms need to push 5G globally.

Big Tech
They will always be growing.

Semiconductors
More and more things need semis. I would buy most of them. TXN, QCOM, MRVL, AMD, INTC, NVDA, UMC, TSMC, etc.

author: UWwolfman
body:
Nvidia's supplies GPU's to both manufactures and retailers. This includes companies like BestBuy, Dell, Hp, Asus, EVGA, MSI, etc. Any changes to their suggested MSRP has to be fairly negotiated with all interested parties. Also, the supply issues are temporary, and raising prices can potentially anger their customer base which could have longer term impact.

However, Nvidia can effectively "raise prices" by adjusting how they prioritize manufacturing and introducing new more expensive models.

author: onyxengine
body: Nvidia is a buy more and hold, ai powered consumer products are coming as is an increase in manufacturing powered by ai.  Nvidia is a market leader and the efficiency of their products for reducing training times compared to standard CPUs that ship with electronics is exponential. An algo that takes 4 hrs to train on my pc, will train in 5 minutes or less with the right setup.  Ai is going to be ubiquitous, people will be using it in their day to day within the next 10 to 15 years.  Nvidia and companies like it are going to power the most transformative revolution in technology we have ever seen.  There are barely any good ai products yet but they are coming.

author: Disposable_Canadian
body:
Look at the books ultimately.  

What do the Financials say?  What's their sales, what is their cash on hand, cash burn rate, book value per share.   Cook it down.

Now chop sales 25%.  What's the business look like after a black swan event?  

I'm a value investor, granted i have some really high risk, but I do love me a company with profits, low cash burn, and a share price / book value ratio below 3.0.  How does that ratio look like with competitors in same market place.  Does that value make sense or is the share price over valued, ie. Tesla, Nvidia, where fomo drove price up and if you strip away the fomo, you're left with a low priced share.

Good moat is important, diversified income stream, doesn't only rely on gov or retail etc.

author: ryan7714
body:
Jim Cramer Trims AMD, Refuses To Sell Any Nvidia Stock: Here's Why

12/1/21, 12:00
December 1, 2021 01:00 PM ET (BZ Newswire) -- Long Ideas

Advanced Micro Devices Inc (NASDAQ:AMD) is up more than 70% year-to-date, so Jim Cramer decided to lock in profits and trim his position.

"We are trimming AMD this morning solely for portfolio management purposes and not out of any change to our bullish long-term view of the company," Cramer said Wednesday in a letter to members of CNBC's "Investing Club."

He noted that he purchased AMD stock in February and is realizing an 80% gain by selling shares today.

See Also: Check Out What Whales Are Doing With AMD

Despite citing prudent portfolio management as the reason for trimming AMD, Cramer said he refuses to sell any shares of NVIDIA Corp (NASDAQ:NVDA), which is up more than 150% year-to-date.

"I'm being a pig in Nvidia," Cramer said Wednesday on CNBC. "Because this may be a $10 trillion stock."

AMD, NVDA Price Action: At publication time, AMD was down 0.93% at $156.84, while Nvidia was up 0.35% at $328.05.
